awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The RISE Program - Research in Interdisciplinary STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States depends on a large and diverse workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. In 2012, it was forecast that the US would need an additional 1 million STEM college graduates over a decade to remain globally competitive. Yet, the majority of students who enter college with intentions to major in a STEM discipline do not actually complete a STEM degree. Improving the retention of undergraduate students in STEM is thus a critical national priority. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) project will address this need by hosting the Research in Interdisciplinary STEM Education (RISE) program at Washington State University. Over the course of three years, RISE will immerse diverse cohorts of 10 undergraduate students each summer in authentic research focused on STEM workforce development. 

While most undergraduate STEM education reform efforts have focused on teaching and learning at the undergraduate level, it is also important to understand the connections to K-12 and informal education settings, and to view STEM learning as a lifelong, life-wide phenomenon. The RISE scholars will advance STEM inclusion and diversity by investigating critical research questions related to STEM pathways, informal STEM education, and authentic STEM disciplinary practices. The RISE REU program will recruit undergraduate students from primarily non-PhD-granting institutions, with a particular focus on recruiting students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields. RISE scholars will participate in extensive mentoring by faculty, graduate students, and peers; a series of professional skills workshops; and cohort-building activities to increase a sense of belonging and STEM identity. RISE participants will gain understandings of the importance of collaboration in STEM, the role of educational research in improving STEM education, and STEM career pathways. A comprehensive longitudinal evaluation plan will examine changes in the RISE scholars' understanding of, appreciation for, and pursuit of career possibilities in STEM and STEM education research. Ultimately, the REU RISE project is expected to contribute to a more vibrant and inclusive STEM workforce while advancing research in STEM education.

The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in areas of research funded by NSF. This REU project is supported by NSF's Education & Human Resources Directorate Core Research (ECR) Program and its Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The Research in Interdisciplinary STEM Education (RISE) program at Washington State University was a summer research experience focused on inclusivity and diversity in STEM education. Our core faculty team, with expertise across three colleges and four departments, mentored undergraduates in studying lifelong, life-wide STEM learning, including STEM pathways, informal STEM education, and engaging undergraduates in authentic STEM practices. RISE used an interdisciplinary approach to engage participants in examining inclusive STEM workforce development from multiple perspectives.

 

The RISE program immersed 29 undergraduates in research on STEM workforce development. Students examined the experiences of individuals navigating diverse pathways into and through STEM fields. We recruited primarily from non-PhD-granting institutions (62%) with a strong focus on underrepresented groups. 69% of our participants identified as female, 45% as persons excluded due to ethnicity or race (PEER), and 38% as first-generation.The program fostered a collaborative, interdisciplinary research environment where students tackled authentic STEM education questions.

REU students participated in a variety of activities to enhance their research skills and build a sense of community.

  • Weekly seminars: These sessions covered essential topics like research methods, scientific writing, and graduate school preparation.
  • Individual meetings: Students met regularly with their faculty mentors to discuss their research projects and analyze scientific literature.
  • Lab meetings: Held once or twice a week, these meetings provided a platform for students to present data, discuss research findings with the lab group, and participate in activities like mini-journal clubs.
  • Social events: From barbeques to day trips around the Pacific Northwest, faculty-organized social events fostered a sense of community among REU students. Students also utilized social media platforms to connect and plan their own activities.

The program's success is evident through positive feedback from faculty mentors, external evaluations, and student surveys. The program has also resulted in numerous scholarly products (conference presentations and publications) co-authored with RISE participants. Our participants continued into STEM career pathways including entering graduate school programs related to STEM and STEM education, taking K-12 STEM teaching positions, and continuing their STEM-related research through continued grant funding and fellowships (e.g., the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program).
